threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: If you sets roll dice multiple times can you predict what kind of results will happen? How different is rolling 2d6 compared to 1d12?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993940
The easiest way to see those things is with the probability generating function
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability-generating_function

The pgf of a single d6 roll is
[eqn]\left(\frac{1}{6} z + \frac{1}{6} z^2 + \frac{1}{6} z^3 + \frac{1}{6} z^4 + \frac{1}{6} z^5 + \frac{1}{6} z^6\right) [/eqn]
The coeffitcient of [math]z^i[/math] is the probability that the result is [math]i[/math].

Now if you throw nd6 then the pgf is just the n-th power
[eqn]\left(\frac{1}{6} z + \frac{1}{6} z^2 + \frac{1}{6} z^3 + \frac{1}{6} z^4 + \frac{1}{6} z^5 + \frac{1}{6} z^6\right)^n [/eqn]
For n=2 it's
[eqn]\left(\frac{1}{6} z + \frac{1}{6} z^2 + \frac{1}{6} z^3 + \frac{1}{6} z^4 + \frac{1}{6} z^5 + \frac{1}{6} z^6\right)^2 = \frac{1}{36} \left(z^2 + 2 z^3 + 3 z^4 + 4 z^5 + 5 z^6 + 6 z^7 + 5 z^8 + 4 z^9 + 3 z^{10} + 2 z^{11} + z^{12}\right)[/eqn]

Meanwhile a d12 gives the pgf
[eqn] \frac{1}{12} \left(z + z^2 + z^3 + z^4 + z^5 + z^6 + z^7 + z^8 + z^9 + z^{10} + z^{11} + z^{12} \right) [/eqn]

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993971

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993979
Yes, you can even mix the type of dice. Throwing one d4 and one d12 and adding the result gives the distribution with the pgf

[eqn] \frac{1}{48} \left(z + z^2 + z^3 + z^4 \right) \left(z + z^2 + z^3 + z^4 + z^5 + z^6 + z^7 + z^8 + z^9 + z^{10} + z^{11} + z^{12} \right) [/eqn]

threads.com: Isn't the probability will always be 50% regardless of past events?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14992302
If you're about to flip a coin, the odds of it being heads or tails is the same regardless of past flips. This is because we are only looking at the odds and outcome of one specific flip. However, the example in the OP image is not looking at a single flip. It is looking at multiple flips, specifically two. Each of the specific outcomes (HH, HT, TH, TT) individually have 25% probability of occurring. We are deciding that "at least one coin lands on heads" is a success in this case, and three out of four of those specific outcomes are successful in that regard. Therefore the odds of at least one heads in two flips becomes 75%.
At least one coin getting heads in x flips will become more likely as the size of x increases. It starts at 50% (because we're only looking at a single flip), it continues to 75% (as explained above), then it goes to 87.5%. A way to make this intuitive is to look at it backwards. The only way that our condition does not get satisfied is if every single coin flip results in tails. The more coin flips, the less likely it becomes for every single one to be tails.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14992302
In probabilities, there are always two different viewpoints to regard some problem:
1. probability of a single event
2. probability that an outcome event will happen over a succession of tries.

There's no such thing as wave function collapse. Prior to the scientist observing the cat, the cat is in a superposition of |alive> + |dead>. After observation, the scientist becomes entangled with the cat and the scientist/cat system is, relative to the perspective of an outsider, in a superposition of |cat is alive>|scientist sees cat is alive> + |cat is dead>|scientist sees cat is dead>. Quantum descriptions are all relative to the perspective you're talking about. If that third perspective observed the scientist/cat system, then he would become entangled and the system would be in a superposition relative to a 4th party.

Base 1 works

1 = 1

111 = 3

1 + 1 = 11
111 + 11111 = 11111111

111 = 111 x 111 = 111111111
111
111

Math people don't want you to know this

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14993207
In the base, whenever you get to the number which is the base you move to the next digit. However in base 1, you start at 0, then you count to 1. But because you got to 1, you now have to write zero and get to the next digit. But since this is a 1, you have to write 0 and move to the next digit. And so on. Eventually you spend your entire life writing zeros and moving to the next digit until finally you die and the people who discover your body realize you're just a madman.

What you're doing isn't base 1. There really is no such thing as base 1 as attempting to follow the conventions around bases would lead to an infinite number of work to write down a single number since 1^x=1^y for any two integers x,y. You're simply just stating the definitions of natural numbers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14986633
Pure in your head calculation:
>factorise 72
72=8*9=(2^3)*(3^2)
>calculate phi(72)
phi(72)=72*(1-1/2)*(1-1/3)=72*1/3=24
>reduce exponent mod phi(72)
4825=1 (mod 24)
>Euler's theorem
25^4825=25^1=25 (mod 72)

threads.sub: NASA unironically got moon rocket working
threads.com:
https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/11/15/science/nasa-artemis-moon-launch

NASA's Artemis 1 rocket blasted off the Kennedy Space Center in the early hours of Wednesday, "lighting up the night sky and accelerating on a journey that will take an astronaut-less capsule around the moon and back," reports the New York Times

At around 1:47 a.m. Eastern time, the four engines on the rocket's core stage ignited, along with two skinnier side boosters. As the countdown hit zero, clamps holding the rocket down let go, and the vehicle slipped Earth's bonds. A few minutes later, the side boosters and then the giant core stage dropped away. The rocket's upper engine then ignited to carry the Orion spacecraft, where astronauts will sit during later missions, toward orbit. Less than the two hours after launch, the upper stage will fire one last time to send Orion on a path toward the moon. On Monday, Orion will pass within 60 miles of the moon's surface. After going around the moon for a couple of weeks, Orion will head back to Earth, splashing down on Dec. 11 in the Pacific Ocean, about 60 miles off the coast of California.

This flight is a crucial test for NASA's Artemis program that aims to put astronauts to moon for real.
